content: TCS: Pseudorandomness and Private-Key Encryption Pseudorandomness and Private-Key Encryption Private-Key Encryption This encryption(åŠ å¯†) problem is starting form the transmission question: two people need to transmit information while avoiding others to know the content. The resolution is to maintain a â€˜keyâ€™ kkk by two people and one can use kkk to encrypt information while the other can use it to decrypt Validity A pair of polynomial-time computable functions (Enc,Dec)(\text{Enc}, \text{Dec})(Enc,Dec) is a valid private key encryption scheme if for every nâˆˆNn\in \mathbb{N}nâˆˆN, kâˆˆ{0,1}nk\in \{0, 1\}^{n}kâˆˆ{0,1}n,and xxx, we haveDec(k,Enc(k,x))=x \text{Dec}(k, \text{Enc}(k, x)) = xDec(k,Enc(k,x))=x And we have the length of the ciphertext(å¯†æ–‡) is no less than that of the plaintext, written as: lc(n)â‰¥lp(n)l_{c}(n) \geq l_{p}(n) lcâ€‹(n)â‰¥lpâ€‹(n) Security We need to define the security with following assumption: A cryptosystem should be secure even if everything about the system, except the key, is public knowledge. Due to this assumption, the kkk must be generated randomly. So, letâ€™s define the security: A valid encryption scheme (Enc,Dec)(\text{Enc}, \text{Dec})(Enc,Dec) with plaintext length l(â‹…)l(\cdot)l(â‹…) is perfectly secret if for every nâˆˆNn\in \mathbb{N}nâˆˆN and plaintexts x0,x1âˆˆ{0,1}l(n)x_{0}, x_{1} \in \{0, 1\}^{l(n)}x0â€‹,x1â€‹âˆˆ{0,1}l(n), the following two distributions Y0Y_{0}Y0â€‹and Y1Y_{1}Y1â€‹ over {0,1}âˆ—\{0, 1\}^{*}{0,1}âˆ— are identical:YiY_{i}Yiâ€‹ is obtained by sampling kkk and outputting Enc(k,xi)\text{Enc}(k, x_{i})Enc(k,xiâ€‹) for i=0,1i = 0, 1i=0,1. Definition Analysis We have a secrecy experiment as follows: Sample kâˆˆ{0,1}nk \in \{0, 1\}^{n}kâˆˆ{0,1}n Adversary A\mathcal{A}A outputs x0,x1x_{0}, x_{1}x0â€‹,x1â€‹ given input 1n1^{n}1n Randomly choose bbb and send y=Enc(k,xb)y = \text{Enc}(k, x_{b})y=Enc(k,xbâ€‹) to A\mathcal{A}A A\mathcal{A}A returns bâ€²âˆˆ{0,1}b'\in\{0, 1\}bâ€²âˆˆ{0,1} If b=bâ€²b = b'b=bâ€², A\mathcal{A}A wins We can prove A\mathcal{A}A has at most 12\frac{1}{2}21â€‹ probability to succeed under perfectly secret. P(Y=yâ€‰âˆ£â€‰b=i)=P(Yi=y)=p(y)\begin{align*} P(Y = y\,|\, b = i) &= P(Y_{i} = y) = p(y)\end{align*}P(Y=yâˆ£b=i)â€‹=P(Yiâ€‹=y)=p(y)â€‹And P(Y=y)=p(y)P(Y = y) = p(y)P(Y=y)=p(y) due to YYY is perfect, so:P(Y=y,b=i)=P(b=i)P(Y=yâ€‰âˆ£â€‰b=i)=P(b=i)p(y)=P(b=i)P(Y=y)\begin{align*} P(Y = y, b = i) &= P(b = i)P(Y = y \,|\, b = i) \\ &= P(b = i)p(y) \\ &= P(b = i)P(Y = y)\end{align*}P(Y=y,b=i)â€‹=P(b=i)P(Y=yâˆ£b=i)=P(b=i)p(y)=P(b=i)P(Y=y)â€‹This means YYY is independent to bbb, so A\mathcal{A}A cannot improve its probability to win by getting yyy Construction Give the One-time pad construction: lp(n)=lc(n)=nEnc(k,x)=xâŠ•kDec(k,c)=kâŠ•c\begin{align*} l_{p}(n) = l_{c}&(n) = n \\ \text{Enc}(k, x) &= x \oplus k \\ \text{Dec}(k, c) &= k \oplus c\end{align*}lpâ€‹(n)=lcâ€‹Enc(k,x)Dec(k,c)â€‹(n)=n=xâŠ•k=kâŠ•câ€‹ In this construction, we have one glaring dis advantage, that is the kkk has the same length of plaintext! This is necessary for perfect secrecy: For every perfectly secret encryption scheme, the length function lp(n)l_{p}(n)lpâ€‹(n) satisfies lp(n)â‰¤nl_{p}(n)\leq nlpâ€‹(n)â‰¤n Computational Secrecy and PRG The long kkk is unadorable in reality. So we use computational secrecy instead. An encryption scheme is computationally secret if no probabilistic polynomial-time(PPT) algorithms can break it. Let Enc,Dec\text{Enc}, \text{Dec}Enc,Dec be a valid encryption scheme. The scheme is computationally secret if, for every PPT adversary algorithm A\mathcal{A}A in the secrecy experiment, there is negligible function negl\text{negl}negl such thatP(AÂ succ)â‰¤12+negl(n) P(\mathcal{A} \text{ succ}) \leq \frac{1}{2} + \text{negl}(n)P(AÂ succ)â‰¤21â€‹+negl(n)where the probability is taken over the randomness of A\mathcal{A}A and the experiment. Pseudorandom Generators Definition: A cryptographic pseudorandom generator (PRG) with stretch l(â‹…)l(\cdot)l(â‹…) is a PPT computable function G:{0,1}âˆ—â†’{0,1}âˆ—G: \{0, 1\}^{*} \to \{0, 1\}^{*}G:{0,1}âˆ—â†’{0,1}âˆ— such that:âˆ€â€‰nâˆˆN\forall \, n\in \mathbb{N}âˆ€nâˆˆN and sâˆˆ{0,1}ns\in \{0, 1\}^{n}sâˆˆ{0,1}n, âˆ£G(s)âˆ£=l(n)|G(s)| = l(n)âˆ£G(s)âˆ£=l(n)For any poly-algorithm A\mathcal{A}A, sâˆˆ{0,1}ns\in \{0, 1\}^{n}sâˆˆ{0,1}n and râˆˆ{0,1}l(n)r\in \{0, 1\}^{l(n)}râˆˆ{0,1}l(n):âˆ£P(A((G(s)))=1)âˆ’P(A((r))=1)âˆ£=negl(n) |{P (\mathcal{A}((G(s))) = 1) - P (\mathcal{A}((r)) =1)}| = \text{negl}(n)âˆ£P(A((G(s)))=1)âˆ’P(A((r))=1)âˆ£=negl(n) Intuitively, this means we can get the difference between output of PRG G(â‹…)G(\cdot)G(â‹…) and a actual random output rrr in a negligible probability. Its existance is obtained by the cryptographic PRG conjecture: PRG with l(n)=naâˆ€aâˆˆNl(n) = n^{a}\quad \forall a\in\mathbb{N}l(n)=naâˆ€aâˆˆN exists. If the cryptographic PRG conjecture is true, then computationally secret encryption exists for l(n)â‰¥naâˆ€aâˆˆNl(n) \geq n^{a}\quad \forall a\in\mathbb{N}l(n)â‰¥naâˆ€aâˆˆN Enc(k,x)=xâŠ•G(k)Dec(c,k)=câŠ•G(k)\begin{align*} \text{Enc}(k, x) &= x \oplus G(k) \\ \text{Dec}(c, k) &= c \oplus G(k)\end{align*}Enc(k,x)Dec(c,k)â€‹=xâŠ•G(k)=câŠ•G(k)â€‹ This can be proved to be computation secret by contradiction proof, which is to construct a adversary for PRG by the assuming contradiction. CPA Security and PRF Choose Plaintext Attack (CPA) The CPA experiments is similar to secrecy experiments, while A\mathcal{A}A can interact freely with Enc(k,â‹…)\text{Enc}(k, \cdot)Enc(k,â‹…) as a black-box. An encryption scheme (Enc,Dec)(\text{Enc}, \text{Dec})(Enc,Dec) is CPA-secure if, for all PPT adversary A\mathcal{A}A, there exists a negligible function negl\text{negl}negl such thatP(AÂ succ)â‰¤12+negl(n) P(\mathcal{A} \text{ succ}) \leq \frac{1}{2} + \text{negl}(n)P(AÂ succ)â‰¤21â€‹+negl(n) All CPA-secure encryption scheme must be probabilistic otherwise A\mathcal{A}A can query all Enc(k,x)\text{Enc}(k, x)Enc(k,x) to get ciphertexts and compare. Pseudorandom Functions (PRF) Consider a keyed family of functions: Fk:{0,1}âˆ—â†’{0,1}âˆ—F_{k}: \{0, 1\}^{*} \to \{0, 1\}^{*}Fkâ€‹:{0,1}âˆ—â†’{0,1}âˆ—, then we can define PRF as follows: Let FkF_{k}Fkâ€‹ be a keyed family of functions that is efficient and length-preserving. We say FkF_{k}Fkâ€‹ is a pseudorandom function if, for all PPT distinguishers D\mathcal{D}D, there exists a negligible function negl\text{negl}negl such that:âˆ£P(DFk(â‹…)(1n)=1)âˆ’P(Dfn(â‹…)(1n)=1)âˆ£â‰¤negl(n) |{P \bigl( D^{F_k(\cdot)}(1^n) = 1 \bigr) - P \bigl( D^{f_n(\cdot)}(1^n) = 1 \bigr)}| \le \text{negl}(n)âˆ£P(DFkâ€‹(â‹…)(1n)=1)âˆ’P(Dfnâ€‹(â‹…)(1n)=1)âˆ£â‰¤negl(n)where kâ†{0,1}nk\gets\{0, 1\}^{n}kâ†{0,1}n is chosen uniformly at random and fnf_{n}fnâ€‹ is chosen uniformly from the set of functions mapping nnn-bit strings to nnn-bit strings. Intuitively, this means we can get the difference between PRF Fk(â‹…)F_{k}(\cdot)Fkâ€‹(â‹…) and a actual random funtions fff in a negligible probability. PRF => CPA-secure Encryption Let FFF be a PRF. Define a CPA-secuee private-key encryption scheme for messages of length nnn as follows: Enc(k,x)=âŸ¨r,Fk(r)âŠ•xâŸ©\text{Enc}(k, x) = \langle r, F_{k}(r)\oplus x \rangleEnc(k,x)=âŸ¨r,Fkâ€‹(r)âŠ•xâŸ©Dec(k,âŸ¨r,sâŸ©)=Fk(r)âŠ•s\text{Dec}(k, \langle r, s\rangle) = F_{k}(r) \oplus sDec(k,âŸ¨r,sâŸ©)=Fkâ€‹(r)âŠ•sIn this râ†{0,1}nr\gets\{0, 1\}^{n}râ†{0,1}n is randomly chosen. Proof is as follows, we use contradiction-proof and construct a contradiction to PRF with assumption.
